Today trying to recover 
from this experiment.

All right. Just a little science here

Institute of Food Technologists annual

- fun meeting to be at--
- Yep. Food technologists.

suggests that there is a correlation 
between preferences for spicy food and

So, here's what we're about to test. 
We're about to find out who's more of a

risk-taker. The person who can go further
on the Scoville Scale is more of a

risk-taker and probably should 
get some sort of award.

You may have heard of the Scoville Scale.
This is a measurement of the intensity of

the spiciness. We're gonna start with bell
peppers and we're gonna go all the way

to the habanero. Yes, we realize there are
peppers that are hotter than the habanero,

So this is a competition, right? Go

- This is a green pepper.

comments.text:
Jalapenos are nasty little things. They aren't very spicy as peppers go, 
but I find them to pack more of a punch than more intense peppers like 
Cayenne and Habenero.
Of course then you've got Ghost peppers, which above the tip of a toothpick 
soaked in it, feel like eating (delicious) molten iron. And the highest up 
I've ever gone was a 4million SHU house challenge sauce at a hot sauce 
specialty store.
It was hot enough for me to suffer mild dizziness and hallucinations after 
consuming the end of a toothpick soaked in it.﻿
